newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: ASIAN EXOTICS - Asian currencies range-bound.
newsitem.headline: ASIAN EXOTICS - Asian currencies range-bound.

text.p: * Rupiah softened against the dollar on ample liquidity and concerns over political unrest ahead of elections.
* Ringgit broke through 2.5120 barrier as offshore funds accumulated dollars.
* Baht firmed against the dollar after the dollar weakened against the yen on Japan's March trade surplus
* Dollar steadied against the Singapore unit, with eyes on March trade data expected to be released on April 21.
Activity in most Asian currencies was mostly muted by midday on Thursday.
Indonesian rupiah eased against the dollar on ample liquidity and concerns over political unrest, dealers said.
They said operators were a bit worried at the opening, one day after a new bank reserve requirement rate became effective, but adequate supply helped calm the market.
A five percent reserve rate was made effective on Wednesday.
One local bank dealer said flush rupiah supply led players to go slightly long on dollars due to the extended weekend.
Dealers in Singapore said demand for the dollar was likely to improve against the rupiah amid continued political unrest ahead of the Indonesian May 29 general elections.
Spot rupiah was at 2,408.5/9.5 at 0430 GMT against an opening of 2,407.75/08.75.
Bank Indonesia kept its intervention band at 2,401/2,593 and the conversion band at 2,401/2,449 on Wednesday.
The Indonesia market will be closed on Friday for a Moslem festival and will reopen on Monday.
Malaysian ringgit eased against the greenback and broke the 2.5120 barrier. Dealers said the ringgit was weighed by concerns of potential rifts among key political players in the country.
However, the ringgit's downside was capped by fears of Bank Negara's intervention.
The ringgit was seen within the 2.5100/30 range at 0430 GMT. Its support and resistance were pegged at 2.5020 and 2.5160, respectively.
The Thai baht strengthened against the dollar as Japan's March trade figures dampened the greenback against the yen, dealers said.
The baht was at 26.071/26.076 to the dollar at 0430 GMT against 26.080/26.085 late on Wednesday.
"The market remained slow. But some dollar short covering by Singaporean players is likely to emerge later today ahead of the long weekend there," said one dealer at a local bank.
The Bank of Thailand set the mid-rate at 26.08 per dollar compared with 26.09 on Wednesday.

The Singapore dollar was range-bound at 1.4410-1.4420 to the dollar. Dealers said activity was light ahead of the long weekend. The market awaited March trade data, expected to be released on April 21, for a clearer indication of economic health.
According to dealers, non-oil domestic exports were likely to show a decline of three to six percent. A Reuters poll of economists on Thursday forecast a 4.5 percent drop.
-- Madhav Reddy in Kuala Lumpur (603-206 2323), Mantik Kusjanto in Jakarta (6221-384-6364), James Mclean in Bangkok (662-652-0642) and Angela Tan in Singapore (65-8703083)
